query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 Per che mia donna «Manda fuor la vampa 8 del tuo disio», mi disse, «sì ch’ella esca 9 segnata bene de la interna stampa:
10 non perché nostra conoscenza cresca 11 per tuo parlare, ma perché t’ausi 12 a dir la sete, sì che l’uom ti mesca».
query.result:
**English:**
7 For which my lady said to me, "Send forth the flame 8 of your desire, so that it may emerge 9 clearly marked with the inner stamp:
10 not because our knowledge grows 11 through your speaking, but so that you may dare 12 to tell your thirst, so that a man may mix for you."
**Cornish:**
7 Rag henna ow leveris vystresses "Kas an flam 8 a'th dhisir", hi a leveris dhym, "vel ylliffo 9 merkys da yn selyow a-ves".
10 Nyns yw rag henna yma an gonisogeth 11 a wra kreskis gans dha leverel, mes rag henna 12 y'th galloseth rag leverel dha set, vel ylliffo 13 den a wra meska dhis."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Così diss’ io a quella luce stessa 29 che pria m’avea parlato; e come volle 30 Beatrice, fu la mia voglia confessa.
query.result:
**English:**
28 Thus I said to that same light 29 that had spoken to me before; and as Beatrice wished, 30 my desire was confessed.
**Cornish:**
28 Henna a leveris dhe henna golow 29 ow tos a wra leveris dhym kyns; ha dell leveris 30 Beatrice, vy dhisir veu confessa.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Né per ambage, in che la gente folle 32 già s’inviscava pria che fosse anciso 33 l’Agnel di Dio che le peccata tolle,
34 ma per chiare parole e con preciso 35 latin rispuose quello amor paterno, 36 chiuso e parvente del suo proprio riso:
37 «La contingenza, che fuor del quaderno 38 de la vostra matera non si stende, 39 tutta è dipinta nel cospetto etterno;
40 necessità però quindi non prende 41 se non come dal viso in che si specchia 42 nave che per torrente giù discende.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Not through ambiguities, in which foolish people 32 once ensnared themselves before the Lamb of God was slain 33 who takes away the sins of the world,
34 but with clear words and with precise 35 Latin, that paternal love replied, 36 hidden and made visible by its own smile:
37 "Contingency, which does not extend beyond the notebook 38 of your matter, 39 is all depicted in the eternal presence;
40 however, it does not take necessity from there 41 except as a ship that descends down a river 42 takes it from the bank in which it is reflected.
**Cornish:**
31 Nyns yw rag henna a-dro dhe'n ambege, le mayth 32 an pobel fol a wra ensnared kyns 33 veu ledhys an Oen a Dhew a wra tak an pechodow,
34 mes gans gerysow kler ha gans Latin precis 35 henna karanteth paternal a leveris, 36 clos ha parus gans y honan lowen:
37 "An contingency, le mayth nyns yw ow sten 38 a-ves an lyver a'th mater, 39 yw oll peynthys yn an presens etern;
40 Mes nyns yw tak necessity a henna 41 mes dell vel an fas le mayth yma ow spectya 42 long a wra discendya warbarth gans an avon."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Da indi, sì come viene ad orecchia 44 dolce armonia da organo, mi viene 45 a vista il tempo che ti s’apparecchia.
query.result:
**English:**
43 From there, just as sweet harmony comes to the ear 44 from an organ, there comes to 45 my sight the time that is preparing for you.
**Cornish:**
43 A henna, dell dell dhe'n clust 44 harmoni dowrus a organ, dhe'm dheus 45 dhe'm golwg an amser a wra parotti rag dhis.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 Qual si partio Ipolito d’Atene 47 per la spietata e perfida noverca, 48 tal di Fiorenza partir ti convene.
query.result:
**English:**
46 As Hippolytus departed from Athens 47 because of his pitiless and treacherous stepmother, 48 so you must depart from Florence.
**Cornish:**
46 Dell dell Ipolito a partias a Athen 47 rag y'n noverca spietus ha perfidus, 48 henna dell ti a wra parti a Florença.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Questo si vuole e questo già si cerca, 50 e tosto verrà fatto a chi ciò pensa 51 là dove Cristo tutto dì si merca.
query.result:
**English:**
49 This is what is desired and this is already being sought, 50 and it will soon be done by those who think about it, 51 there where Christ is bought and sold every day.
**Cornish:**
49 Hemm awos henna ha henna yw kehevelys, 50 ha bys vyth efan dhegemmir a wravyth henna, 51 ena le mayth Krist dhysprennys pub dydh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 La colpa seguirà la parte offensa 53 in grido, come suol; ma la vendetta 54 fia testimonio al ver che la dispensa.
query.result:
**English:**
52 The fault will follow the offended party 53 with a cry, as it usually does; but vengeance 54 will bear witness to the truth that excuses it.
**Cornish:**
52 An golh a sew an rann offendythys 53 yn gri, dell yw an arver; mes an venjans 54 a vydh tysti dhe'n gwir a'y dyskarth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Tu lascerai ogne cosa diletta 56 più caramente; e questo è quello strale 57 che l’arco de lo essilio pria saetta.
query.result:
**English:**
55 You will leave behind everything you hold dear, 56 most preciously; and this is the arrow 57 that the bow of exile shoots first.
**Cornish:**
55 Ti a wra vyth pub traow a gar, 56 moyha karantek; ha henna yw an saeth 57 a wra an bogh a'n esili a saetha kyns.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Tu proverai sì come sa di sale 59 lo pane altrui, e come è duro calle 60 lo scendere e ’l salir per l’altrui scale.
query.result:
**English:**
58 You will experience how salty is the bread of others, 59 and how hard is the path 60 of going up and down another man's stairs.
**Cornish:**
58 Ti a brof vyth pyth yw blas an holen aral, 59 ha pyth yw kales an fordh 60 a sevel ha mosya war gresen aral.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Di sua bestialitate il suo processo 68 farà la prova; sì ch’a te fia bello 69 averti fatta parte per te stesso.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Its bestiality will prove its own downfall; 68 so that it will be good for you 69 to have made a party for yourself alone.
**Cornish:**
67 Y bestalita a wra provia y dhiskwedhes, 68 lemmyn byth da vyth brassa 69 ow tos owrth dhys hwegen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Con lui vedrai colui che ’mpresso fue, 77 nascendo, sì da questa stella forte, 78 che notabili fier l’opere sue.
query.result:
**English:**
76 With him you will see the one who was stamped, 77 at birth, by this powerful star, 78 so that his works will be remarkable.
**Cornish:**
76 Ganso genafi an neb a veu sevelys, 77 genys, gans an steren meur ma, 78 lemmyn y oberow a vydh arbennek.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Le sue magnificenze conosciute 86 saranno ancora, sì che ’ suoi nemici 87 non ne potran tener le lingue mute.
query.result:
**English:**
85 His magnificence will be known 86 so that his enemies 87 will not be able to keep their tongues silent.
**Cornish:**
85 Y voynderow a vydh aswonnys, 86 lemmyn lemmyn, lemmyn byth y enebow 87 nag a wra gallos ow tavesow mudh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Poi giunse: «Figlio, queste son le chiose 95 di quel che ti fu detto; ecco le ’nsidie 96 che dietro a pochi giri son nascose.
query.result:
**English:**
94 Then he said: "Son, these are the things 95 Of what was told to you; behold the snares 96 That are hidden after a few turns.
**Cornish:**
94 Wosa hwelas: "Mab, hemma yw an traow 95 A veu leverys dhys; sel an peryllow 96 A yw kudyn wosa nebes torn."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Non vo’ però ch’a’ tuoi vicini invidie, 98 poscia che s’infutura la tua vita 99 vie più là che ’l punir di lor perfidie».
query.result:
**English:**
97 I do not want you to envy your neighbors, 98 Since your life will extend 99 Far beyond the punishment of their perfidies.
**Cornish:**
97 Mes na vynnaf bos dhys dhe'th nessa, 98 Wosa bos dha vewnas dhe'th bewnas 99 Moy pella ages an pynna an perfidie."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Poi che, tacendo, si mostrò spedita 101 l’anima santa di metter la trama 102 in quella tela ch’io le porsi ordita,
103 io cominciai, come colui che brama, 104 dubitando, consiglio da persona 105 che vede e vuol dirittamente e ama:
106 «Ben veggio, padre mio, sì come sprona 107 lo tempo verso me, per colpo darmi 108 tal, ch’è più grave a chi più s’abbandona;
109 per che di provedenza è buon ch’io m’armi, 110 sì che, se loco m’è tolto più caro, 111 io non perdessi li altri per miei carmi.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Then, by being silent, the holy soul showed herself ready 101 To put the weft into that fabric that I had offered her as warp,
102 I began, like one who longs for, 103 While doubting, advice from a person 104 Who sees and wants and loves rightly:
105 "I see well, my father, how time spurs 106 Towards me, to deal me a blow 107 That is heavier to him who surrenders more;
108 Therefore it is good for me to arm myself with foresight, 109 So that, if a place dearer to me is taken away, 110 I would not lose the others because of my songs.
**Cornish:**
100 Wosa, dre wosa mudh, an eneval spedyt 101 An eneval sans dhe'n trama dhe'n gwea 102 Yn an gwelyow henna a veu leverys dhym,
103 Yth commensis, kepar ha neb a wra brama, 104 Dre wosa dowtya, cowsel gans person 105 A wel ha'n kar ha'n kar yn gwella:
106 "Yn gwella yn dha, fy mador, kepar ha'n spurn 107 An amser dhe'm, rag dhynna dhym colp 108 Henwys ages dhe neb a wra moy esedhys;
109 Rag henna yw dha dhym dhe'm dhe'n armys, 110 Mar plek a veu kemeres gansow moy ker, 111 Yv na gollaf an erel rag fy carmow."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Giù per lo mondo sanza fine amaro, 113 e per lo monte del cui bel cacume 114 li occhi de la mia donna mi levaro,
115 e poscia per lo ciel, di lume in lume, 116 ho io appreso quel che s’io ridico, 117 a molti fia sapor di forte agrume;
118 e s’io al vero son timido amico, 119 temo di perder viver tra coloro 120 che questo tempo chiameranno antico».
query.result:
**English:**
112 Down through the world without end of bitterness, 113 And up the mountain from whose fair summit 114 The eyes of my lady lifted me,
115 And then through heaven, from light to light, 116 I have learned that which, if I tell again, 117 Will be to many a taste of sharp sourness;
118 And if I am a timid friend to the truth, 119 I fear to lose my life among those 120 Who will call this time ancient.
**Cornish:**
112 Gwartha an bys vythfyt amer, 113 Ha'n wartha an menydh a'y bel top 114 An lagha'm myghternes a'm syrhas,
115 Ha'n wosa dre'n nef, a golow dhe golow, 116 Yv dyskys henna pyth vyth leverel, 117 A fia dhe moy sawor a sur sournes;
118 Ha'm yw kov a'n gwir, 119 Yv owth dhe golla bewnas ynter an re 120 A wra galwa an amser ma koth."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Ma nondimen, rimossa ogne menzogna, 128 tutta tua visïon fa manifesta; 129 e lascia pur grattar dov’ è la rogna.
query.result:
**English:**
127 But nevertheless, removing every lie, 128 Make all your vision manifest; 129 And just let them scratch where the itch is.
**Cornish:**
127 Mes oll an keth, ow pos henna oll an golon, 128 Gwra dha oll dha visyon dhe'n eyl, 129 Ha lell henna dhe skraffa ena a'n rogna.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Ché se la voce tua sarà molesta 131 nel primo gusto, vital nodrimento 132 lascerà poi, quando sarà digesta.
query.result:
**English:**
130 For if your voice will be bitter 131 At the first taste, it will leave 132 Vital nourishment, once it is digested.
**Cornish:**
130 Rag mar dha lav a fia sur 131 Yn an kynsa blas, bywydh nowydh 132 A wra lell wosa, pan vo dhegestys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Questo tuo grido farà come vento, 134 che le più alte cime più percuote; 135 e ciò non fa d’onor poco argomento.
query.result:
**English:**
133 This cry of yours will act like the wind, 134 Which strikes the highest peaks the most; 135 And this is no small argument of honor.
**Cornish:**
133 Dha grydh ma a wra kepar dhe'n gwyns, 134 A wra'n toppa moy ughella moy a wra'n skeus; 135 Ha'n henna na wra argument byghan a onor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 Però ti son mostrate in queste rote, 137 nel monte e ne la valle dolorosa 138 pur l’anime che son di fama note,
139 che l’animo di quel ch’ode, non posa 140 né ferma fede per essempro ch’aia 141 la sua radice incognita e ascosa,
142 né per altro argomento che non paia».
query.result:
**English:**
136 Therefore, in these circles, on the mountain and in the sorrowful valley, 137 You have been shown only the souls that are famous,
138 So that the mind of the one who hears does not rest 139 Nor establish faith through an example that has 140 Its root unknown and hidden,
141 Nor through any other argument that does not appear.
**Cornish:**
136 Rag henna, yn hemma rowtow, wartha an menydh ha'n dowr dolorus, 137 An enevalow hep a veu notys aga hanow,
138 Rag henna an eneval a neb a wra klev, na wra pos, 140 Na wra gwra feyth dre esempel a wra 141 Y'n gwreydh ankow ha kudyn,
142 Na dre argument erel a na wra par."
